question: How do symptoms of ammonia toxicity manifest differently in aquarium fish versus plants sensitive to NH4+?
generated_answer:
In aquarium fish, symptoms of ammonia toxicity include extensive damage to tissues, especially the gills and kidney, decreased resistance to disease, gasping at the surface, inflamed gills, red streaks or inflammation in the fins, inflamed eyes or anus, loss of appetite, hovering at the bottom of the tank, and lethargy. High levels of ammonia can lead to ammonia poisoning, which can be fatal.

In plants sensitive to NH4+, symptoms of NH4+ toxicity include yellowing of leaves, inhibited growth, especially root elongation, lowering of the root/leaf ratio, reduced yield, and inhibited germination and seedling establishment. Excessive NH4+ can also affect the absorption of certain nutrient elements and the balance of hormones, leading to a decrease in the concentration of soluble carbonic acid and an increase in the concentration of amino acids. Additionally, NH4+ stress can induce a large amount of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in plants, causing further damage.

The key differences are that in fish, ammonia toxicity primarily affects the gills and kidneys, leading to respiratory and immune system issues, while in plants, NH4+ toxicity affects growth, nutrient absorption, and hormone balance, leading to morphological changes and reduced yield.
ground_truth_answer: In ammonia-sensitive plants like tomatoes, potatoes, and barley, symptoms include leaf yellowing (appearing first on lower old leaves in mature plants and new leaves in young plants), inhibited growth especially in root elongation, reduced root-to-leaf ratio, decreased yield, and impaired seed germination. Additionally, plants show reduced absorption of K+, Mg2+, and Ca2+. In contrast, aquarium fish exhibit different symptoms including loss of appetite, hovering at tank bottom (especially in surface-dwelling fish), gasping at the surface, red streaks or inflammation in the gills, and inflamed eyes or anus. Fish also suffer extensive tissue damage, particularly to gills and kidneys, and show decreased disease resistance.
